TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant had been a judge for DATE . By virtue of an amendment to the law on ORG DATE , which came into effect on DATE , the status of a “ retired judge ” was created ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

On DATE the applicant who had retired on DATE on grounds of ill health acquired the status of a “ retired judge ” . Under the applicable provisions of domestic law retired judges were entitled , as from DATE , to a special retirement pension equivalent to seventyfive per cent of their last full salary ( sędziowski stan spoczynku ) DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE LAW entered into force . By a further amendment to the DATE Law of DATE , which came into effect on CARDINAL DATE , retired judges who had acquired the right to a special retirement pension were required to submit a declaration under that LAW . In DATE the applicant made a declaration under the provisions of that Act to the effect that she had never secretly collaborated with the NORP secret services .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on an unspecified date , the Commissioner of Public Interest applied to ORG , acting as the firstinstance lustration court , to institute proceedings in the applicant ’s case under LAW on the ground that she had lied in her lustration declaration by denying that she had collaborated with the secret services . He referred to documents showing that in DATE the applicant had agreed to collaborate and from DATE until DATE had submitted CARDINAL written reports .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings the applicant was represented by a lawyer . The case file could be consulted by the applicant and her lawyer in the secret registry of the lustration court . They were authorised to make notes . However , the notes could be made only in special notebooks which were subsequently sealed and deposited in the registry . It was possible for them to make notes , but not to take the notes from the registry .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG , acting as the firstinstance court , held a hearing in the applicant ’s case . The hearing was not public . She was questioned by the court and commented on the evidence at the court ’s disposal . The case file was composed of the applicant ’s lustration declaration , copies of certain documents contained in the applicant ’s file compiled by the communist secret police and the Commissioner ’s application for lustration proceedings to be instituted .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court gave a judgment in which it found that the applicant had made an untrue lustration declaration because she had been a willing secret collaborator of the NORP secret services . It observed that the documents in the case file were incomplete , but that they were nevertheless sufficient to find that the applicant had been a secret collaborator . The applicant appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the same court , acting as a court of appeal , upheld the contested judgment , holding that the evidence in the case file was sufficient to find that the applicant had knowingly and intentionally collaborated with the NORP secret services . The applicant submitted a cassation appeal to ORG , which dismissed it by a judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . From DATE to DATE the applicant received MONEY ( ORG ) per month ( ORG MONEY after tax ) as the special retirement pension .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , ORG , acting upon a request submitted by the Minister of ORG , instituted proceedings to divest her of her status as a retired judge . It also decided that payment of the special retirement pension to the applicant should cease with effect from DATE .

CARDINAL . In her pleadings submitted to the ORG the applicant argued that a decision to divest her of her special pension was unlawful as the requirements of LAW did not apply to retired judges . Even supposing that retired judges were obliged to make a lustration declaration , they could not be divested of their status under the provisions of LAW . In any event , such a decision could only be given after disciplinary proceedings had been conducted under the provisions of LAW , but no such proceedings had been conducted in her case . She requested that payment of her special pension be resumed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted a resolution by which the applicant was divested of the special pension to which she was entitled on account of her status as a retired judge . The applicant appealed , essentially reiterating the arguments which she had raised in her pleadings submitted to the ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed her appeal against this resolution .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant requested the social insurance authority to grant her an ordinary retirement pension . Her request was refused by a decision of DATE on the ground that the applicant had not been working for the statutory period of DATE necessary for an entitlement to a retirement pension to accrue .

CARDINAL . Later on , in DATE , she was granted a partial disability pension ( renta z tytułu częściowej niezdolności do pracy ) from DATE , DATE when she had lodged a request for an ordinary social insurance pension , to DATE , when the applicant was to reach the statutory retirement age , in a DATE amount of ORG CARDINAL ( ORG CARDINAL after tax ) .
CARDINAL . As from DATE the applicant ’s pension was reassessed against inflation . From then on she was paid ORG CARDINAL per month ( ORG CARDINAL after tax ) .
CARDINAL . As from DATE the applicant has received her DATE retirement pension in the amount of ORG CARDINAL ( ORG CARDINAL after tax ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE LAW ( Ustawa o ujawnieniu pracy lub służby w organach bezpieczeństwa państwa lub współpracy z nimi w latach DATE osób pełniących funkcje publiczne ) entered into force . Its purpose was to ensure transparency as regards those people exercising public functions who had been secret collaborators with the secret service during the communist era . It lost its binding force on DATE . The relevant domestic law and practice have been extensively summarised in the following judgments : PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL . On DATE amendments of CARDINAL DATE to the PERSON on ORG DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) entered into force ( “ the DATE amendments ” ) . The amendments introduced the status of a “ retired judge ” . By a further amendment which entered into force on DATE it was provided that a judge , with the status of a retired judge , who had retired on grounds , inter alia , of age or illhealth should be entitled to remuneration equal to CARDINAL per cent of his or her basic salary plus a bonus calculated on the basis of DATE of service .
CARDINAL . On DATE further amendments of DATE to the DATE PERSON came into effect ( “ the DATE amendments ” ) . The amendments provided , so far as relevant :
“ Article CARDINAL .... § CARDINAL . A retired judge shall be obliged to keep the dignity of the position of a judge .

§ CARDINAL . A retired judge shall take disciplinary responsibility for a failure to maintain the dignity of the position of judge after having retired and for any failures to maintain such dignity when serving as a judge . ”
CARDINAL . The DATE amendments further provided , inter alia , as follows :
“ LAW . Judges ... who have acquired the right to the retirement pension or disability pension shall submit the declaration envisaged under LAW of [ LAW ] .

LAW . Retired judges ... who worked for or served in the [ ORG ’s security services ] or who have submitted untrue declarations concerning such service or employment or collaboration with [ such services ] shall lose the right to retired judge status and to remuneration in the retired status .

§ CARDINAL . The circumstances referred to in § CARDINAL shall be ascertained according to the procedure laid down in [ LAW ] . The loss of the rights shall occur from the date of issue of the decision . ”
